Verify that:

- It's reasonably fast with various searches

- The button to enable files/search.exclude settings is checked by default on a new workspace, and works as expected
- Results from open files are returned
- UTF-16 files are searched

data.title: There's no way to reset 3-way split to equal sizes
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: Ubuntu

Steps to Reproduce:

1. create (split) 3 editor "groups" 
2. resize the group splitting
3. try to reset the groups to an even split...

With 2 editor groups you can double click the splitter, but for the 3-way split there's no way to get all 3 groups reset to equal sizes.

data.title: VScode only remembers tabstops for most recently triggered snippets. It must remember all.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
# Feature request

Vscode only remembers tabstops for the most recently triggered snippet. I wish VScode can  remember all the tabstops for previous snippets as well, not only the recent one.


Ultisnips has become one of the most important killer-plugins for vim since it supports this powerful feature. We might refer to it.

## In detail:
Let us say we have the following simple snippet. This will expand `printf("\n");` with the prefix of `prf`. It contains 3 tabstops.
```
"printf": {
		"prefix": "prf",
		"body": [
			"printf(\"${1:%s}\\n\"$2);$3"
		],	
		"description": "printf snippet"
	}
```

If I type `prf<tab>`, my cursor will be located after the first double quote so I can type some strings. 
Just for a test, let me try to expand another prf snippet there. So the total typings would be:
`prf<tab>prf<tab>`
and then the result would be
`"printf("printf("%s\n");\n");`

However, if I press tabstop jump trigger (which I mapped to `<c-j>` instead of the default `<tab>` to avoid confusion), the cursor only moves to 
```
"printf("printf("%s\n");\n");
                     ^ ^
            here and here, not further
```

I know not many editors are supporting this feature (except for vim and emacs). This is a necessary, killer feature required for VScode in order to fully migrate from vim.

data.title: Test: Keybindings & Keyboard Dispatching changes
data.body:
Test for #17521

- [x] Windows - @mousetraps 
- [x] Linux - @rebornix 
- [x] Mac - @jrieken 

Complexity: 4

### Windows

**There should be no observable difference compared to the previous VS Code stable version (i.e. dispatching still works on `e.keyCode`)**. There are a few improvements, we now detect keyboard layout changes and we display some dead key based keybindings better.

Note: this is not a test plan of default keyboard shortcuts. Based on keyboard layouts, defaults might be all over the place (i.e. poor). We do not ship with kb layout specific default shortcuts.

Please check by sampling that we render the correct labels for keybindings in the kb layouts: US, Latin American, UK, German, French. Hint: I use the touch keyboard to validate. (i.e. please pick an action, find its keybinding from our UI, press those key, validate that action executes, do this multiple times). You can use `Developer: Inspect Key Mappings` to take a look behind the scenes.

### Linux & Mac

**There should be no observable difference compared to the previous VS Code stable version for the US keyboard layout**. On Mac, we detect keyboard layout changes.

Note: this is not a test plan of default keyboard shortcuts. Based on keyboard layouts, defaults might be all over the place (i.e. poor). We do not ship with kb layout specific default shortcuts.

Key code based default shortcuts will be transformed, with heuristics to scan code based shortcuts. The heuristics are about what each scan code combination produces. e.g. ctrl+/ is ctrl+shift+7 on GER because shift+7 produces /. This is a heuristic and there might be edge cases where it might not work well.

Recording a keypress might sometimes (depends on heuristics) resort to using scan codes (i.e. the define keybinding widget). Scan codes look like "[This]".

Please check by sampling that we render the correct labels for keybindings in the kb layouts: 
* mac: US, Spanish, British, German, French
* linux: us, gb, latam, br, es,  
Please also use the define keybinding widget and check that what you press results in something that can be persisted in `keybindings.json` and repeated (pressing it again triggers the bound command under the same kb layout).

Hint: I use the keyboard utilities that render a kb on screen to validate (i.e. please pick an action, find its keybinding from our UI, press those key, validate that action executes, do this multiple times). You can use `Developer: Inspect Key Mappings` to take a look behind the scenes.

---

Example analysis:
https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/4084#issuecomment-288800403
https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/8568#issuecomment-288760042

data.title: How to re-enable 'extension-tips-service', after pressing "Don't show again"?

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
I accidently pressed "don't show again' for the help message prompted.

I cannot receive any recommendations for extensions or other helpful info after that.
 **How do I re-enable this feature?**

In addition to that, I have a feature request related with this issue.
## Feature request: 
Please get rid of the button
`don't show it again`
and replace it with a small message something like: 
**To disable this message, turn off** `"extension-tips-service":true` **in settings.json.**

Please make it easy for us (the users) to toggle certain features, not one-sided. It's very time-consuming to find a way to revert it back.

data.title: context menus not getting hooked up to commands in Insiders
data.body:
i found this because my extension https://github.com/chrisdias/vscode-opennewinstance stopped working when you right click on a folder.  Same problem happens with Erich's npm extension.

- VSCode Version: insiders 1.11.0 c995ecf
- OS Version: MacOS

Steps to Reproduce:

1. clone https://github.com/chrisdias/vscode-opennewinstance, run npm install, open code-insiders
2. but a breakpoint in extension.ts on the line 16 
3. press F5
4. in development instance, open some workspace that has folders in it
5. right click on a folder and choose "Open New Workbench Here"

Result: Nothing happens, breakpoint is not hit, the command is not executed.

6. Open command palette
7. execute command "Open New Workbench Here" 

Result: breakpoint is hit.

However, notice that `e` is `undefined`.  in stable, it comes in as `null`.

data.title: Test: SCM API
data.body:
Test for #2824

- [x] Windows - @dbaeumer  
- [x] OS X - @sandy081 
- [x] Linux - @chrmarti 

Complexity: 5

Good news: you're gonna write an SCM provider! 👊 

1. Go through the [docs](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-docs/blob/vnext/docs/extensionAPI/api-scm.md).
2. Go through the [API itself](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/vscode.d.ts#L4541:L4744). There ain't much.
3. Make something. You don't need to actually implement _an_ SCM provider. But test the API, try to create some resources, some menu items, see what breaks.

After [generating a new extension](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/extensions/yocode), edit its `package.json`, change `engines.vscode` to `*` and rerun `npm install`. This will fetch the latest `vscode.d.ts` from `master`.

Please provide feedback on the docs, api and issues all through this repository.

data.title: Installing extensions from a package
data.body:
Take the following use-case:

I've downloaded and installed a .deb installation on a Linux (or ,msi for windows) computer, that doesn't have access to the WWW.

As far as I can see, extensions are only install-able through VSCode itself, and you must download it.
Considering I don't have an internet connection to download the extension, a possible solution would be to allow `packaged-extentions`, so that you can make a `standalone extension installation package` and install it to your VSCode in the WWW-less PC.

I assume this might have been discussed before, so if it's already been decided not to allow this, I would thank for an explanation, since I do believe this is something that might benefit a lot of people.

data.title: List Filter Viewlet
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: MacOS 10.12.3

It would be nice to have a list filter viewlet that I can bind to a key command.  This would effectively allow me to filter out a list when focused with vim-like key commands.

The idea is that once invoked, a text area would appear and allow you to enter your filter criteria.  The list would either filter items or move your selection to the appropriate input.

Eg:
I might use the following key commands to navigate to File Explorer, and then filter out the list to a particluar file:

```
// Place your key bindings in this file to overwrite the defaults
[
  {
    "key": "ctrl+h",
    "command": "workbench.view.explorer",
    "when": "editorTextFocus"
  },
  // New (proposed)
  {
    "key": "/",
    "command": "list.showFilterViewlet",
    "when": "explorerViewletVisible && filesExplorerFocus"
  }
]```

data.title: Test: Git as an SCM provider, round 2
data.body:
Test for #22131

- [x] Windows - @waderyan 
- [x] OS X - @isidorn
- [x] Linux - @aeschli 

Complexity: 5

Give Git a good last smoke test.

These features have been there since last month:

- Git output channel
- Dirty diff (gutter decorations)
- SCM viewlet
  - Click, keyboard nav
  - Title, inline, context menu actions
  - Commit box
- Git status bar
- Merge conflict decorations
- Fetch happens automatically, unless configured otherwise
- SCM Viewlet shows progress during operations
- Global commands
- Editor title actions
- No repo workspace shows "Git Init" action
- Scoped git workspace: open a folder within a git repo, everything should work
- Editor selections
  - Staging, unstaging (global commands)
  - Reverting (global command)
- If you set a [git commit template](https://robots.thoughtbot.com/better-commit-messages-with-a-gitmessage-template) it is picked as a default value for the commit box
- If you use a repository that requires authentication, you get prompted for credentials
- Clone global command

These features are new this month:

- Global commands to stage, unstage and discard selected changes in the diff editor
- Multiple selection. The inline & context actions should work according to the selection
- Askpass. Use Code on a repository which requires authentication (clone a private repo from Github using an HTTPS url, for example). Code should provide affordance for authenticating.
- Localization. Run Code in `pseudo` locale and try to find non-localized strings.

data.title: Failed to execute git (fatal: bad config line 1)
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: Windows 10.0.14393 Build 14393

Hi, im using Cygwin as an integrated terminal, but havent changed any git settings in VSCode at all, so it _should_ be using the system defaults.

However, recently ive been getting 'Failed to execute git' errors. I cant seem to work out the pattern of when i get them, theyre just seemingly intermittent. Restarting VSCode doesnt help.

Here's the error im seeing in developer tools:
```
ipc.cp.ts:152 [IPC Library: Git] Uncaught Exception:  Failed to execute git {
  "exitCode": 128,
  "gitErrorCode": null,
  "gitCommand": "rev-parse",
  "stdout": null,
  "stderr": "fatal: bad config line 1 in file C:/cygwin64/home/harry/.gitconfig\n"
}
    (anonymous function) @ ipc.cp.ts:152
```

There is no problem with my git config, however my suspicion is that the reason im hitting the error is because git is trying to load the config file from `C:/cygwin64/home/harry/.gitconfig`, however this is simply symlinked in cygwin to `/cygdrive/c/Users/harry/.gitconfig`, for convenience when using git in cygwin.

I cant work out how to tell it not to try and use that path for my global git config file. I dont know why it isnt just taking it from `C:\Users\harry\.gitconfig` ????

data.title: Local installed extension commands are shown but cannot be invoked
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: macOS 10.11.6

Hello there, I've developed an extension which works under `extension development mode`, but if I installed it from a vsce generated packages, extension's commands are shown when I type `CMD + Shift + P`, but cannot be invoked, it returns `commandX not found` error. Also in the `activate()` method of my extension it should show an information message about extension is activated, however such message is not shown if I installed the package locally (Extension is activated in any events).

I've tested it under macOS and Linux, it seems under macOS extension is enabled (I can only disable or uninstall from extension tab) and under Linux it cannot enabled, it constantly shows a reload button despite of if you've pressed it before.

Steps to Reproduce:
1. `vsce package // One warning: Couldn't detect the repository where this extension is published. Images might be broken in its README.`
2. `code --install-extension extension.vsix // Returns extension successfully installed`
3.  `code .`
4. `CMD + Shift + P`
5. `Select command X from dropdown \\ command x not found`

Piece of my extension code:
```typescript
export function activate(ctx: vscode.ExtensionContext) {
  vscode.window.showInformationMessage("Activating extension")

  ctx.subscriptions.push(vscode.commands.registerCommand('ext.initWorkspace', () => {
    initWorkspace()
  }));

  };
```

Piece of my package.json:
```json
{
  ...
  "engines": {
    "vscode": "^1.9.0"
  },
  "categories": [
    "Other"
  ],
  "activationEvents": [
    "*"
  ],
  "main": "./out/extension",
  "contributes": {
    "snippets": [
      {
        "language": "json",
        "path": "./src/snippets/manifestSnippets.json"
      }
    ],
    "commands": [
      {
        "command": "ext.initWorkspace",
        "title": "Initialize Workspace"
      }
    ]
  },
  "scripts": {
    "vscode:prepublish": "tsc -p ./",
    "compile": "tsc -watch -p ./",
    "postinstall": "node ./node_modules/vscode/bin/install"
  },
  "devDependencies": {
    "@types/node": "^6.0.40",
    "@types/request": "0.0.36",
    "request": "^2.79.0",
    "typescript": "^2.1.5",
    "vscode": "^1.0.0"
  }
}

```

data.title: Should the terminal set TERM_PROGRAM and TERM_PROGRAM_VERSION?
Test workspace theming
data.body:
Test for #3112:

Complexity: 3

- [x] Windows - @isidorn  - doing Quite Light theme
- [x] OSX - @joaomoreno
- [x] Linux - @roblourens - Solarized Dark

Color themes can now be defined in a new JSON file format that holds syntax token colors as well as workbench colors. Additionally a custom theme can also be defined in the settings.

To test, define your own custom theme based on built-in theme, e.g. 'Red'. 
- add to your settings:
```json
	"workbench.colorTheme": "Custom Theme",
	"workbench.customColorTheme": {
		"extends": "Red",
		"type": "dark",
		"colors": {

		}
	}
```
- use code completion to see the available color keys. Color values must be in the form #RRGGBB or #RRGGBBAA.
- Verify that the existing color keys work
- Try to find good colors for the all missing colors in our built-in themes
   - make a PR with the updated theme. The goal is that we can update some of the themes for March, in particular Kimbie Dark, Red, Solarized Dark and Tomorrow Blue.
   - To convert a tmTheme to a .json file: `node ./build/npm/update-theme.js ./extensions/theme-kimbie-dark/themes/Kimbie_dark.tmTheme ./extensions/theme-kimbie-dark/themes/kimbie-dark-color-theme.json`
   - there are plenty of colors that are not themable yet. No need to file a bug for each, but please so for the ones that disturb the theming experience most.
  - feedback on any area, be it the custom color theme setting or color key names is highly welcome. This is all considered work in progress.

data.title: Standalone editor cannot be run out of dev anymore
data.body:
Steps to Reproduce:

* clone https://github.com/Microsoft/monaco-editor next to vscode
* `monaco-editor` and `vscode` should be sibling folders
* run `gulp watch` as usual in `vscode`
* run `npm install .` in `monaco-editor`
* open `monaco-editor/test/index.html` in a browser (file protocol will do)
* click on `dev` next to monaco-editor the url should now contain `?editor=dev`

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/900690/24364078/8957fd5a-12c6-11e7-8d13-bcefad269091.png)

data.title: Themes: wrong color applied to urls
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.11.0-insider (c995ecf2e94a00aa7eda81ed842e787b999e83ae, 2017-03-27T06:11:09.027Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|typings-installer|benjaminromano|0.2.0|
|vscode-eslint|dbaeumer|1.2.8|
|theme-dracula|dracula-theme|1.8.0|
|tslint|eg2|0.8.1|
|vscode-great-icons|emmanuelbeziat|1.1.44|
|Theme-azure|gerane|0.0.2|
|docthis|joelday|0.4.3|
|theme-material-theme|jprestidge|1.0.1|
|vs-color-picker|lihui|0.6.0|
|Theme-MaterialKit|ms-vscode|0.1.1|
|debugger-for-chrome|msjsdiag|2.7.0|
|view-in-browser|qinjia|0.0.5|
|java|redhat|0.0.13|
|ActiveFileInStatusBar|RoscoP|1.0.2|
|vscode-hexdump|slevesque|1.2.1|
|eval|Stormspirit|0.0.6|
|omnipascal|Wosi|0.13.0|;

---
Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open an HTML file

Urls seem to use some random different color than the one that is supposed to be used for the context. See this screenshot where the url should be yellow and turns bright red instead:

![linksvscode](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/199648/24363139/2a702792-130f-11e7-8f39-2a7c65a16ac7.png)

Same problem happens when url is inside comments:

![linksvscode2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/199648/24363160/40cf76aa-130f-11e7-8b00-a23a503c92cb.png)
